results.title: CRWDSPCR
results.creator_credit: Cunningham Dance Foundation and Elliot Caplan
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Merce Cunningham Dance Company = Cunningham Dance Foundation”.
CRWDSPCR features the choreographic process of Merce Cunningham’s work with the computer program “LifeForms”. Cunningham, an inveterate explorer of new technology, became interested in “how the computer opens the eye to detail — the way a photograph does.” Shot over the course of one year, CRWDSPCR follows the dancers from Cunningham’s dance company as they transform his computerized images to staged reality. Music by John King. Reference: http://www.merce.org/filmvideo.html

results.title: Crustaceans: lobsters, barnacles, shrimps and their relative
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and William A. Anderson
results.brief_description: The appearances, habitat and behaviour of the most important types of Crustaceans are shown. The distinguishing features of the five tuypes are illustrated with close-up views of the animals in their natural environment. Designed for high school classes in biology and zoology.

results.title: Crustacea from the gulf of Maine
results.brief_description: Balanus, Caprella, Crago, Hippolyte, Homarus, and Pagarus serve to illustrate various groups pf crustaceans found along the rocky coast of Maine. The picture opens with a colony of barnacles in action, followed by high magnifications of the cirri. Several specimens shed their integuments to allow for continual growth. Large individuals dredged from deep water are similarly shown. The skeleton shrimp shows its protective blending of form and colour with the algal background, and we see the peculiar structure of this obscure animal. The prawn and lobster reveal decapod structure and activity and demonstrate such features as the main divisions of the body, the mouth parts and the sensory and ecomotor appendages. The hermit crabs protect themselves by occupying the shells of various gastropod molluscs, and one individual deprived of its shell is seem to enter a new one in time to avoid capture of another hermit crab.

results.title: Crush
results.creator_credit: Hibiscus Films, Bridget Ikin and Alison MacLean
results.brief_description: Alison Maclean’s (“Kitchen sink”, “Jesus’ son”) debut feature is a macabre psychological study of obsession, sexual jealousy and female friendships. Marcia Gay Harden stars as the brazen and destructive Lane, a classic femme fatale archetype who finds herself stuck in the sleepy New Zealand town of Rotorua after she and her girlfriend Christina (Donogh Rees) are involved in a near fatal car accident. Lane walks away from the crash site unharmed, leaving her friend for dead and lands on the doorstep of the shy and tomboyish Angela (Caitlin Bossley) and her novelist father Colin (William Zappa). The awkward teen soon develops a crush on the more sexually confident Lane, who in turn makes a play for Angela’s father, leaving the abandoned girl devastated and thirsty for revenge. Maclean uses the shifting power plays as an astute metaphor for New Zealand’s own confused relationship to cultural identity, shrewdly casting an American as the self assured and opportunistic outsider, while setting the film in the mainly Maori community of Rotorua. Cast also includes Peter Smith and Jon Brazier.

results.title: Crusades: 1095-1291
results.brief_description: Discusses the social, economic and religious climate that gave birth and then momentum to the Crusades and treats the various Crusades from a human viewpoint.

results.title: Crusades. Pt. 2
results.brief_description: Terry Jones continues his fascinating account of the history of the Crusades. Although romanticised in literature and films, the Crusades history is filled with horrific tales of unbridled bloodshed and violence under the banners of “Righteousness and Faith”. Jones examines this period not just from a singularly European perspective but also from the perspective of the Islamic world. “Jihad” looks at the unification of disparate Muslim groups under one powerful leader - Saladin. His brilliant leadership formed the foundations of the ultimate victory by the “Infidels”. “Destruction” focuses on the enigmatic character of Richard the Lionheart and concludes the history of the Crusades, which ended bloodlessly with the Fourth Crusade in which not one “Infidel” was killed.

results.title: Crusades. Pt. 1
results.brief_description: 900 years ago, Christian Europe was seized by a religious fervour that changed the course of history and the world. Tens of thousands of men, women and children - knights and peasants, old and young - marched 3000 miles to recapture the Holy City of Jerusalem. Terry Jones narrates this fascinating documentary with exceptional special effects, actors, local people and computer wizardry in an attempt to demystify the romantic image of the Crusades. “Pilgrims in Arms” discusses who the Crusaders were and why they went. A pilgrimage to liberate the Holy City ensured absolution from sin, while failure to comply meant excommunication. “Jerusalem” looks at the actual physical conditions endured by the Crusaders and the art of medieval warfare.

results.title: Crusade
results.creator_credit: Frank Donovan Associates, American Cancer Society and Frank Donovan
results.brief_description: Describes the three-fold program of the American Cancer Society: depicts the volunteer effort to save lives through education and to give help to the cancer patient in service; and discusses the hope for the future of the national research program. Narrated by Spencer Tracy.

results.title: Crumb
results.creator_credit: Superior Pictures, Lynn O'Donnell and Terry Zwigoff
results.brief_description: This surreal documentary about animator and director Robert Crumb was partly financed by David Lynch. Crumb was an underground counter-cultural comic artist who confronted taboos by examining sex, drugs and violence in his animated films and comics, most famously in “Fritz the Cat.” Crumb has continued to work in his anarchic manner but the collapse of the counterculture led to his increasing alienation and separation from the commercial art world. This documentary is confronting as an intimate study of an eccentric life, but it also reveals much about the nexus between imagination and personality, between family history and present relationships. Sometimes almost brutally naked, “Crumb” is an innovative study of a uniquely talented animator and comic. Winner of the Grand Jury Prize at the Sundance Film Festival.

results.title: Cruising
results.creator_credit: Lorimar Film Entertainment, Jerry Weintraub and William Friedkin
results.brief_description: On its initial release in 1980, “Cruising” was the target of criticism and protest by gay and lesbian activists who saw it as a negative and destructive portrayal of urban gay life. In retrospect, “Cruising” proves to be one of the most fascinating and chilling dramas about sexuality and violence to come out of Hollywood. Al Pacino plays Steve Burns, a heterosexual cop who has to go undercover in New York’s gay S/M subculture to uncover the identity of a serial killer who is murdering gay young men. As Burns becomes increasingly immersed in the highly sexualised world of gay S/M, he finds his own identity, centred on fixed definitions of gender and monogamous fidelity, challenged by the seductive allure of promiscuity, fast sex and drugs. As the film unfolds, his search for the killer becomes confused by the unleashing of his own repressed desires. Director Friedkin is known for his fast-paced and highly kinetic movies such as “The French connection” and “The Exorcist”, “Cruising” is equally taut and frightening. It is also a film which explores graphically the connections between violence, sexuality, homophobia and masculinity. Far from being a destructive portrayal of gay life, “Cruising” refuses neat sociological positive stereotyping and instead offers chilling insights into the aggressive desires of men, whatever their sexuality. Based on the novel by Gerald Walker.
